Headline.Para: S.E.A.View; Australia and Asean - drawing closer in uncertain times

LeadPara.Para: The first-ever special summit between Australia and Asean over the weekend was long in coming.
Although Canberra is the regional body's first dialogue partner, the United States and India managed to hold their own summits with Asean in 2016 and this year, respectively.

TailParas.Para: However, the recent visit by nine Asean leaders, with the notable exception of Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte, reaffirmed Australia's emergence as a regional power broker in its own right.

It has also underlined the blossoming partnership between the two regional players, which share increasingly similar anxieties and interests. The outcome of the summit suggests that both Australia and Asean are perturbed by the uncertain direction of American foreign policy, China's increasing diplomatic and territorial assertiveness in the Asia-Pacific theatre, and a plethora of non-traditional security challenges, in particular terrorism.
For a long time, Australia had stood apart from its South-east Asian neighbours with its decidedly "Western" outlook, anchored by its historical ties to Europe and security alliance with America.

Issues such as immigration have also been a major point of contention, particularly with Indonesia, which has served as a transit point for refugees seeking to enter Australia, while Canberra's strong stance on human rights and democracy issues has often alienated more authoritarian leaders in the region.

Yet, shared anxieties and a sense of opportunity have brought both sides closer than ever. Indonesian President Joko Widodo went so far as to openly support the prospect of Australian "full membership" in Asean.

Ahead of the summit in Sydney, prominent Australian figures such as former prime minister Paul Keating and journalist Graeme Dobell endorsed a similar idea, possibly in the form of an upgraded, associate membership, even if not full-fledged membership in Asean.

To be sure, there remains considerable scepticism about the idea, largely centred on the concern over the unnecessary distraction and division within Asean it would create, while opening the floodgates for membership application from others elsewhere in the Asia-Pacific region.

Proponents, however, say it is time to at least consider the prospect of deeper Australia-Asean integration, given the rapidly shifting geopolitical landscape. Decades down the road, Australia would not want to be left isolated as an outlier "Western" nation, squeezed out by larger Asian neighbours with booming economies, particularly Indonesia, they argue.

Moreover, Australia's financial and human resources can bring added dynamism to Asean's skeletal central bureaucracy. Pooling their resources together, the two can have greater heft in the regional pecking order.

Regardless of whether Asean and Australia will ever move in that direction, what is clear is that there is shared cognisance of the need for deeper and stronger ties. As Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull noted in his speech at last year's Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore: "In this brave new world, we cannot rely on great powers to safeguard our interests."

Both sides seem to agree that they will have to either hang together or risk being hung apart, as America wavers in its commitment to the region, China carves out its own spheres of influence, and climate change and terrorism threaten the broader South-east Asian neighbourhood.

In a thinly veiled rejection of Washington's "America First" policy, Australia and Asean made it clear in their joint Sydney Declaration after the summit that they are committed to enhancing trade and investment and "resisting all forms of protectionism to improve regional development and prosperity".

The stakes for deeper economic integration are high. Up to 12 per cent of Australia's exports are destined for Asean. Two-way trade has hit US$100 billion (S$132 billion) in recent years. Australia also hosts as many as 100,000 students from Asean nations, to the benefit of its education sector.

In an indirect rebuke of China's rising maritime assertiveness, both sides reiterated "the importance of non-militarisation" and urged "self-restraint" in the South China Sea. Both Asean and Australia also expressed support for the full and effective implementation of the 2002 Declaration on the Conduct of Parties in the South China Sea.
During the summit, Mr Joko even proposed joint coordinated patrols among South-east Asian countries in the waterway.
It is still too early to say whether there will be any actual follow-through, but clearly there is a shared threat perception vis-a-vis the maritime disputes in the region.

Given its geographical proximity to the troubled regions of South-east Asia, Australia has also doubled down on its counter-terrorism cooperation with Asean. During the summit, the two sides signed a memorandum of understanding which, among other things, calls for greater sharing of high-grade intelligence. The agreement paves the way for greater cooperation among financial intelligence analysts and law enforcement agencies.

The deepening partnership between Australia and Asean during the two-day summit points to the willingness of middle powers to play a more decisive and independent role in shaping the texture and direction of the post-American order in Asia. Instead of looking to Washington for leadership, smaller powers are taking matters into their own hands in order to preserve a rules-based order in their region.
• Richard Javad Heydarian is a Manila-based author and non-resident fellow at Stratbase ADR Institute for Strategic and International Studies.
